Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: He said you're the only one he ever saw who was better in the air than him.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: ...He said that?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Look, uh...Rafe's dad...he wrote me with the news, and it took me a couple of days to work up the guts to come here and tell you.  I'm not as brave as Rafe, or as noble.  But if there's anything I can ever do to help -- you let me know, okay?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: I understand why Rafe loved you.  You're as strong as he was.

Speaker: yamamoto
Dialogue: Everything real except the fact that no one is shooting back at us.

Speaker: genda
Dialogue: If we achieve surprise, they will offer little resistance.

Speaker: yamamoto
Dialogue: Set up teams of radio operators to send out messages the Americans will intercept, concerning every potential American target in the Pacific.  Include Hawaii -- the clutter will be more confusing that way.

Speaker: genda
Dialogue: Brilliant, Admiral.

Speaker: yamamoto
Dialogue: A brilliant man would find a way not to fight a war.

Speaker: aide
Dialogue: Mr. President, we've received a message from the Argentinian ambassador to Japan. His sources tell him the Japanese are assembling their fleet to attack us.

Speaker: president roosevelt
Dialogue: We're picking up warnings for every American base in the Pacific.  Does this ambassador know the target?

Speaker: aide
Dialogue: Not for sure.  But he thinks it's Pearl Harbor.

Speaker: president roosevelt
Dialogue: Tell the Pentagon.

Speaker: president roosevelt
Dialogue: No, George, I need the practice, in case there's a fire.

Speaker: admiral
Dialogue: The attack seems inevitable.  The question is where?  The way to answer that question is to ask:  if we were the Japanese, how would we do it?

Speaker: vice admiral
Dialogue: Between America and the Far East are the sea lanes where the winds and the currents make the best route for shipping.  Far above is the northern route, between Canada and Russia. Between these two is something they call the Vacant Sea.  If I were the Japs, I'd send a task force there.  You could hide the entire land mass of Asia in the Vacant Sea, and nobody would know.

Speaker: admiral
Dialogue: So they pop out and attack where?

Speaker: vice admiral
Dialogue: That's the problem, Admiral.  They could hit anywhere they want.

Speaker: dental assistant
Dialogue: Dr. Takanawa, you have a call from Tokyo.

Speaker: dentist
Dialogue: Please excuse me.  Just relax.

Speaker: dentist
Dialogue: Takanawa... Yes?...

Speaker: dentist
Dialogue: Yes, they are all...no wait, I see the big one moving.  The one that's flat on top, what do they call it?...

Speaker: listener
Dialogue: Here's something, over the line from Tokyo.

Speaker: tracer
Dialogue: It's connected to a local dentist.  His office is beside Pearl Harbor.

Speaker: intelligence supervisor
Dialogue: This dentist, is he a spy?

Speaker: listener
Dialogue: Sounds too innocent.  His accent is from the old country.  Somebody official- sounding calls, he thinks it's discourteous not to respond.

Speaker: aide
Dialogue: Sir, we just had an intelligence intercept.  Someone from Tokyo called a local dentist whose office looks over Pearl.  They wanted to know the exact location of the ships.

Speaker: admiral kimmel
Dialogue: Someone from Tokyo asks a dentist how the ships are sitting... What are we supposed to do about that?

Speaker: aide
Dialogue: I...don't know, Sir.  But it just seemed significant.

Speaker: admiral kimmel
Dialogue: Have intelligence keep monitoring him.

Speaker: photographer
Dialogue: Closer, ladies!  Closer!  Now smile!... Great!  Next week I'll show you a print and you can order your Pictures of Paradise!

Speaker: betty
Dialogue: Barbara, here's yours...and Evelyn, here you are.

Speaker: betty
Dialogue: It's been a month and you haven't smiled. We just want you to know we love you.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: What is it with nurses and pilots?

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: You're Walker, right?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Yes Sir.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: That was a nice little stunt you pulled, buzzing the base.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: You liked that?

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: Oh yeah.  I liked it so much I'm cutting you out of the squadron.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Sir?

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: I don't buy that hot dog shit.  So you and your buddies are gonna transfer your planes up to Haleiwa.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Hale-what?

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: You'll love it.  No base, no bars, just lots of sun and aircraft maintenance.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Sir, I --

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: Too late for apologies, Walker.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: I wasn't gonna apologize, Sir.  I was just gonna say it was worth it to feel like a real pilot again, even if it was only for five seconds.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: How's everything?

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: We got some soldiers in traction from a jeep accident, but it's quiet.  Except for the occasional fighter plane buzzing us.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: That might not have been such a good idea.  They're making us fly out of a half-paved airfield.  The real punishment is that I won't be back to the barracks till it's too late for dinner or coffee. So I guess it's goodbye for awhile.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: I was just thinking that war is a series of goodbyes.  Do you think that's why we're meeting.  To help us say goodbye to Rafe?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: I swore not to talk about him tonight, but there's all this stuff I think I ought to tell you, that he didn't get a chance to.  Rafe was...he was lonely.  He had such high expectations of himself that he always felt empty.  The week he met you he told me he felt his heart had always lived in winter, and for the first time in his life he has seen the spring.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: He told me he didn't want to leave me with regret.  Now that's all I have.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Hey, have you seen Pearl Harbor at night?

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: Well...sure.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: From the air?

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: So beautiful!

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Hang on.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: I didn't realize until tonight that I've stopped wanting to live.

Speaker: evelyn's voice
Dialogue: Dearest Rafe --

Speaker: evelyn's voice
Dialogue: ...Every sunset...

Speaker: evelyn's voice
Dialogue: ...gather it's heat into my heart, and send it to you...

Speaker: message boy
Dialogue: Daniel Walker?...

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Rafe!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Evelyn.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: I sent telegrams, I guess the military traffic held them up.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: Why were you sitting here, instead of...

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: I saw you, I couldn't go in, I...just stood there wondering if you knew.  You looked...sad, and I had to sit down a minute.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: How did you?...

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: ...Survive?  I jumped in a patch of fog, and nobody could see me.  I hit the water hard.  And it was so...cold.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: I don't know how long I was in the water. A Norwegian freighter picked me up.  They were headed to Spain.  They docked in La Rota, right beside a German ship, and told me to stay hidden below.  I was afraid they'd turn me in, so I stole some clothes, jumped ship, and found a church, where the priest contacted the resistance, and got me on a freighter to New York.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: I called my folks, then Colonel Doolittle.  The Colonel sent a man to pick me up.  They wanted to debrief me. I told the Colonel I needed to see somebody first, and he had a supply flight heading out in an hour.  I've done a lot of talking.  You haven't said anything.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: I'm just...so amazed, so glad to know that you're okay.  You are okay, aren't you?

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Nothing that won't heal.  I guess.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: It's been...so different, being so sure you were dead.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: I'm so sorry for what you must've gone through, but I'm back.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Maybe I've assumed too much.  Has something changed?  Have you fallen in love?

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: It's all right.  Danny always said I see things with my emotions instead of my eyes.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: It's not your fault, Rafe.  The letter I wrote you, they --

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Don't worry about that.  Guys away from home, lonely, good-hearted women try to cheer them up.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: It's not that I didn't mean everything I wrote.  It's just that -- I thought you were dead.  And now --

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: You're alive!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Aw, God.  Oh my God.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: Rafe --

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Evelyn...

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Don't worry.  I'll find him.

Speaker: betty
Dialogue: This came while you were gone.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: You'd always go sit in a plane whenever you were upset.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Upset?  Why should I be upset?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Let's go get a drink.  Unless you're scared to talk about it.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Drink up.  Then we'll talk.

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: Rafe?!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: They'll go under you because their planes are faster, then they run so you can't catch 'em.  But then they'll come around and take you from behind -- like some Americans will.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Why be sorry?  That's what you feel, it's better to come out with it.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: I didn't mean it.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Sure you did.  So come on.  Say what you think.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Waitress!  Four beers!

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: You don't wanna put beer over mai-tai.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: If you can't keep up, don't drink yours.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: We gotta face some facts here.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: What facts are those?

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: I understand how it could happen.  I know why any guy would love her.  And I can't blame you that it happened.  You thought I was dead, she was grieving, you were trying to help her.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: I was grieving too.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Yeah, right.  Anyway, you didn't know.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: So what are you saying?

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: I'm saying now you do know.  So it's time for you to fuck off.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: You left her.  How's that for a fact?

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: How's this for a fact?  I loved her first.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: You know, you're a lousy drinker. Drinking's supposed to make men feel bigger.  It only makes you stupid.  And weak.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: How's this?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: You want it, you got it.

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: Let 'em fight, they need it.

Speaker: sailor
Dialogue: Is this a private fight or can anybody jump in?

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: That hurt?  I didn't think you had any balls.

Speaker: yamamoto
Dialogue: The submarines will be reaching the harbor soon.  I hope they don't set off the alarm too soon.

Speaker: watch officer
Dialogue: Captain, lookouts report a sighting, two points off the starboard beam.

Speaker: selfridge captain
Dialogue: How big?

Speaker: sonar operator
Dialogue: ...I've lost it.

Speaker: selfridge captain
Dialogue: Probably a blackfish.  I've seen them look like subs.

Speaker: duty officer
Dialogue: Sir, Selfridge reports a contact, then lost it.  Now our sonar reports the contact.

Speaker: intercom
Dialogue: Sir, the Squadron Commander on Selfridge denies permission.

Speaker: intercom
Dialogue: Denies, Sir.  He says it's a blackfish.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: How come you're not pukin'?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: I guess I'm used to it.  I've felt like throwing up every minute since you got back.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Don't blame her, Rafe.  It's not like you're thinking.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Fuck you.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: She loves you.  I know that.  And part of what she loves in me is how much of you she sees in me.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: We were both torn up.  I started dropping by to see her, because we understood what each other felt.  We'd have coffee and try not to talk about you, but we always would.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: She said I was so much like you.  I said, No, I'm not.  I'm like I am because of you, but I'm not you, not as good as you. Everybody else saw me as a loser with a big chip on his shoulder.  But you saw the better part of me, the part of me that could be like you, and changed me. You made me who I am.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: How sweet.  Is that when you put the move on her?

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: That's better.

Speaker: sub commander
Dialogue: Prepare to launch midget sub.

Speaker: lookout
Dialogue: Captain, do you see that, in our wake?

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Could it be one of ours?

Speaker: ellis
Dialogue: Time to shut her down.  That was a good first session.  You'll get the hang of this new radar soon.

Speaker: private
Dialogue: Thank you, Sir.  Hey...what's this?

Speaker: ellis
Dialogue: I've never seen anything like that before.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Watch command... Coming from which direction?... Hold on.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Radar station has picked up a cloud of blips, coming in from the northeast.

Speaker: commander
Dialogue: KGMB is on early.  That means we've got a flight of B-17's coming in from the mainland, they use the radio music for a homing beacon.

Speaker: ellis
Dialogue: All right, Sir.  They say don't worry about it.

Speaker: yamamoto
Dialogue: We have achieved surprise, but their carriers are not in port.  I don't like this.

Speaker: genda
Dialogue: We have a fighter screen up, in case we are attacked, Admiral.

Speaker: yamamoto
Dialogue: We must go ahead.  This is our moment.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Admiral, one of our destroyers reports sinking a sub on its way into Pearl.

Speaker: admiral kimmel
Dialogue: Relay that to Washington...and cancel my golf game.

Speaker: admiral kimmel
Dialogue: Any response from Washington?

Speaker: kimmel's aide
Dialogue: Nothing, Sir.

Speaker: sailor 1
Dialogue: Look at that.

Speaker: sailor 2
Dialogue: It's the Army again, practicing on us.

Speaker: sailor 2
Dialogue: Practice torpedoes.

Speaker: sailor 2
Dialogue: Now listen, you'll hear a little thud when it hits the side of the ship.

Speaker: sailor
Dialogue: Shit!  I'll get some ammo!

Speaker: intercom
Dialogue: Battle stations!  Battle stations!  This is not a drill!

Speaker: bloody officer
Dialogue: Boy!  We need stretcher bearers on the bridge!

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: Oh my God... EVERYBODY TO THE HOSPITAL!

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: Get everything out!  Bandages, sutures -- oh God, the men in traction... Come with me!

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: Cut them down, and take cover!!  Hurry!

Speaker: red
Dialogue: Th-th-th-th-th-

Speaker: red
Dialogue: Th-th-th-th-Dammit!  Th-th-th-

Speaker: red
Dialogue: The Jaaaps!!  The Jaaaps!!

Speaker: billy
Dialogue: Goddamn Japs!

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: Billy!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Get me into a plane!

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Come on!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: You're making a phone call?!

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: This is Walker!  We're under attack!  Get those planes fueled and armed RIGHT NOW!

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: They got Billy.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Come with us!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Where are we going?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Auxiliary field at Haleiwa, ten miles north of here.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: What's there?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Six P-40's.

Speaker: panicked sailor
Dialogue: The water's rising!  It's coming up, we're all gonna drown!

Speaker: terrified sailor
Dialogue: Get me out!  Get me out!

Speaker: terrified sailor
Dialogue: MY FOOT'S CAUGHT!

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: Sum-bitch!

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: They ready, Earl?

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: They'll all fly, but -- oh, shit...

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Cover!

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: You absolute mother-fuckin' son of a bitch!  You shot one of my planes!

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: This ain't a little feud, Earl, it's World War Two!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: They're coming around for another pass. You got extra weapons and ammo?

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: Cock-suckin' right I do!!  In the gun lockers!

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: You guys get those!  Earl, Rafe, come with me!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Danny, over there!  We're in a canyon, they'll come straight down it, we'll get 'em in a crossfire.

Speaker: red
Dialogue: D-don't like it when we fight back, do ya!

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Earl!  You said the planes were ready but -- but what?

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: Of the four left, only one is full of fuel.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Will the others get into the air?

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: Danny, I don't like this fuckin' guy.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Anthony, Red, stay with the guns!  Coma, you cover the cannons!  Joe, Theo, come with us!  Earl, you get on the radio! We're gonna fight these fuckers.

Speaker: joe
Dialogue: How do we do it?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Your call, Rafe.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Get rolling as fast as you can.  Stay low!  We'll use the topography to separate them and then we can take 'em one on one.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: It's tight.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Tighter 'n a bulls ass in fly season. Don't hit the barn.

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: I see six...seven...eight of the cocksuckers!  Don't let 'em hurt my planes.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: They're all over us!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Bet they don't dust crops in Japan.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Danny!  Let's play some chicken!

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: Oh shit, oh shit...

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: You hear my okay?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Yeah.  So you can call me if you need help.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: I got a half a tank.  You?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Little less.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: They're in strafing formation, we'll blow right through their line.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Land of the free.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Home of the brave.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: They're trying to hold formation.  We can chew 'em up!

Speaker: japanese bombardier
Dialogue: West Virginia... Oklahoma... Ah, Arizona.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: Put criticals in ward one, stables in two!  Barbara!  Fill every syringe you can find with stimulant and antibiotic --

Speaker: medic
Dialogue: Where are the doctors?

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: On the third tee.

Speaker: sandra
Dialogue: Evelyn!  Where's the morphine?

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Ain't no time for spectatin'!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: I'm out of ammo!

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: I'm out of fuel!

Speaker: genda
Dialogue: Second attack wave is in the air.

Speaker: disc jockey
Dialogue: All Army, Navy, and Marine personnel to report to duty.

Speaker: general short
Dialogue: Mobilize everything!  We're at war!  Send a message to Washington:  Hostilities with Japan commenced with an air raid on Pearl Harbor.

Speaker: hopkins
Dialogue: Oval Room... Yes, he is.  It's Knox, Mr. President.

Speaker: roosevelt
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: roosevelt
Dialogue: The Japanese have attacked Pearl Harbor.

Speaker: hopkins
Dialogue: My God.  Do we have damage estimates?

Speaker: roosevelt
Dialogue: Our Pacific Fleet, at anchor, unprepared? It's terrible.  It has to be.  And it's not over.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: We need ammo too!

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: Strip it from the wrecks!

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: Who the fuck taught you to fly?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: He did.

Speaker: shimazaki
Dialogue: Second wave, deploy over the military bases.  High level bombers to the air stations, dive bombers attack ships in harbor.  Fighters strafe and cover.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Grab a dinghy and get ammo from the base ammo storeroom.

Speaker: gunnery sergeant
Dialogue: We need weapons and ammo!

Speaker: supply sergeant
Dialogue: You need authorization.

Speaker: gunnery sergeant
Dialogue: The fuck I do!

Speaker: sandra
Dialogue: I can't tell who's gotten morphine and who hasn't!

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: Take a grease pencil and mark an M on the forehead of everyone you stick.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: Don't look for a vein, just poke.

Speaker: sandra
Dialogue: My pen's dry!

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: Use lipstick.  Use ammo belts for tourniquets, use your own nylons if you have to!  Barbara!  Grab anything that will hold a pint of blood and sterilize it.

Speaker: senior doctor
Dialogue: Evelyn!  You have to do the triage! They're bringing them in with trucks!

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: Critical -- front ward!... Give him morphine, he can't wait...

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: Take him outside and cover him; he's dead.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: She's gone too, take her --

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: Go to the base hardware store and get some of those canister spray things they use for killing bugs.

Speaker: orderly
Dialogue: Insecticide?...

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: No, just the sprayers.  We'll fill them with tannic acid, it'll sterilize them and cool the burns!  GO!

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: We're gonna need every bed.  If they can breathe, make 'em get up and move someplace else!

Speaker: genda
Dialogue: We have achieved complete surprise!  The first wave is returning, the second is attacking now, and we have lost only a few planes.  We can launch a third wave, Admiral.

Speaker: yamamoto
Dialogue: The second wave has not returned.  And we have no idea where their carriers are. What is the damage report?

Speaker: communications officer
Dialogue: We have Commander Fuchida on the radio now, Admiral.

Speaker: fuchida's voice
Dialogue: I am over the harbor now...

Speaker: fuchida
Dialogue: We have a tremendous victory.  Many ships damaged, some totally destroyed.  But the Second Wave's attack is being hindered by the smoke.

Speaker: yamamoto
Dialogue: The more we attack, the harder it is to find targets.  And we no longer have surprise.

Speaker: genda
Dialogue: If we launch the third wave and annihilate their fuel depots, we destroy their ability to operate in the Pacific for at least a year!

Speaker: yamamoto
Dialogue: And if we fail, and lose our carriers, we destroy our ability to fight them at all.  As soon as the second wave returns, we will withdraw.

Speaker: conscious soldier
Dialogue: Sarge?!  Where are you, Sarge?

Speaker: medic
Dialogue: We've got two more over here!

Speaker: short
Dialogue: I want lookouts and sentries everywhere, with orders to shoot first and ask questions later.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: You think an invasion possible, General?

Speaker: short
Dialogue: After this morning, we better not consider anything impossible.

Speaker: short
Dialogue: From Washington.  "Intelligence reports an ultimatum from Japan to be given precisely at one p.m.  Washington time. Just what significance the hour set may have we do not know, but be on alert accordingly."

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Well, son, we won't worry about the dinghy today.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: How can we help?

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: What else can we do?

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: There's nothing you can do here, they'll die or they won't, we just --

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: There was a sailor, a black man on the West Virginia, named Dorie Miller.  I'd like to know if he's alive.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Where is the West Virginia?

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: There.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: We're looking for Dorie Miller.

Speaker: dorie
Dialogue: That's me, Sir.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: A friend of ours wanted to be sure you're alive.  Evelyn.  A nurse.

Speaker: dorie
Dialogue: How is she?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Like we all are.

Speaker: dorie
Dialogue: There's something out there I need to get.  Will you help me?

Speaker: dorie
Dialogue: The Arizona.  Hold the dinghy steady, so it doesn't bust open.

Speaker: sailor
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: sailor flashlight
Dialogue: Just hand on.  They'll find us.

Speaker: sailor
Dialogue: How do you know?

Speaker: sailor flashlight
Dialogue: Because we would find them.

Speaker: sailor flashlight
Dialogue: Breathe easy.  Stay calm.

Speaker: sailor
Dialogue: You hear something?

Speaker: sailor
Dialogue: It's letting out air, and letting in water!

Speaker: roosevelt
Dialogue: Yesterday, December 7, 1941 -- a date which will live in infamy -- the United States of American was suddenly and deliberately attacked by naval and air forces of the Empire of Japan.

Speaker: roosevelt
Dialogue: The distance of Hawaii from Japan makes it obvious that the attacks was planned many days or even weeks ago.  During the intervening time the Japanese Government has deliberately sought to deceive the United States by false statements and expressions of hope for continued peace.

Speaker: roosevelt
Dialogue: ...I regret to tell you that many American lives have been lost.

Speaker: roosevelt
Dialogue: Yesterday the Japanese Government also launched an attack against Malaya.  Last night Japanese forces attacked Hong Kong... Guam...

Speaker: roosevelt
Dialogue: ...the Philippine Islands... Wake Island... And this morning the Japanese attacked Midway Island.

Speaker: roosevelt
Dialogue: The facts speak for themselves.  With confidence in our armed forces -- with the unbounding determination of our people -- we will gain the inevitable triumph -- so help us God.  I ask that the Congress declare that since the unprovoked and dastardly attack by Japan on Sunday, December 7, 1941, a state of war --

Speaker: roosevelt's voice
Dialogue: War...war...war...

Speaker: roosevelt
Dialogue: Gentlemen, the crisis we face is not the fact that our enemies believe they can defeat us -- it's the fact that our people believe it too.  I want a plan -- a workable plan -- to hit the heart of Japan, to bomb them the way they have bombed us.

Speaker: admiral
Dialogue: Mr. President, Pearl Harbor caught us because we didn't face facts.  This isn't a time for ignoring them again.  There are no planes in the entire American arsenal capable of covering the distance to Japan from any land base we control while carrying enough bombs to do any damage whatsoever.

Speaker: general marshall
Dialogue: He's right, Mr. President.  The Army has long range bombers, but no place to launch them from.  Midway's too far, China is overrun by Japanese forces, and Russia refuses to go to war with Japan and won't allow us to launch a raid from there.

Speaker: admiral
Dialogue: The navy's planes are small, carry light loads, and have short range.  We would have to get them within a few hundred miles of Japan, and therefore risk our carriers.  And if we lose our carriers, we have no shield against invasion.

Speaker: roosevelt
Dialogue: What if the Japanese did invade?

Speaker: general marshall
Dialogue: We've done studies.  We're confident we would turn them back eventually...after they'd gotten as far as Chicago.

Speaker: admiral
Dialogue: Mr. President...with all respect...what you are asking can't be done.

Speaker: roosevelt
Dialogue: Do not tell me...it can't be done.

Speaker: minister
Dialogue: ...Where is God in this?  Our enemies believe a divine wind protects them.  We see our friends laid out before us, and find it hard to believe in anything at all.

Speaker: minister
Dialogue: Though we cannot understand why our friends should die while we live, we can affirm our truest selves in our belief that any God worth divinity would choose both justice and mercy, and would take these fallen brothers and sisters into eternal peace.  Amen.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: Rafe --

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: I need to tell you something.  I didn't know what it was to lose somebody, to see death and find how much it scares you. That you haven't lived and loved enough. I didn't understand.  Forgive me.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: Rafe... No.  You forgive me.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Of course I forgive you.  I know what you feel for Danny is real.  And your choice is your choice.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: That's what I have to tell you, Rafe.  It wasn't a choice.  It --

Speaker: major
Dialogue: Lieutenant Rafe McCawley?

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Yes, Major.

Speaker: major
Dialogue: Lieutenant Daniel Walker here too?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: I'm Walker.

Speaker: major
Dialogue: You're going Stateside.  We fly out in half an hour.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: What for, Sir?

Speaker: major
Dialogue: Ask Colonel Doolittle.  Those orders are from him.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: I told her not to come.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: This hasn't been easy for any of us.  I feel awful for how it's happened.  But I've seen my first spring too.  Thanks for knowing that's true.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: I heard what you did.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: We can explain, Colonel.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: Explain what?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Whatever is was you heard about us.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: You mean the hula shirts you were flying in?... Or the six planes you shot down? You're both being awarded the Silver Star, and promoted to captain.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Is that the good new, Sir, or --

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: You're just about the only pilots in the Army with actual combat experience, so you're volunteering for a mission I've been ordered to put together.  Do you know what top secret is?

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Well sure, Colonel --

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: Top secret means you help me pick the other pilots, train, and go -- without knowing where you're going until it's too late.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: You can count on us.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: There's only one other thing I can tell you.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: You won't need any goddamn hula shirts.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Attention!

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: Be seated.  The mission you've volunteered for is dangerous.  How dangerous?  Look at the man beside you. It's a good bet that six weeks from now, either you or he will be dead.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Sorry you're gonna die -- cause I'm gonna make it.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: What color flowers you want me to bring to your funeral?

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: In flight school you qualified in single and in multi-engine planes.  You'll be flying multi-engines here.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Bombers.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: I want to introduce a couple of people. Doc White is a flight surgeon; he has volunteered for gunnery training so that he can go on the mission, because we can't spare the weight of an extra man.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: A long range bomber mission.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: ...And Ross Greening, who will oversee your equipment.  Any questions?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Who'll be the first one in, Colonel?  I'd like to volunt --

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: I thought I'd made it clear, I'm not just putting this mission together -- I'm leading it myself.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: I take it back, about the flowers.  We're all gonna die.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: This is what we'll fly -- the B-25. There's one thing you have to be aware of from the very beginning.  You see that private?

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: Green means go.  Red means dead.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: You're having trouble getting airborne in the shorter space because you're not revving the engines enough.  You've got to push them to the limit before you ever start to move.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: We've got to get the weight down.

Speaker: greening
Dialogue: Okay, forty pounds gone.  And in it's place, this.

Speaker: greening
Dialogue: Weight, 3 ounces.  Cost, 20 cents.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: Does it work?

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: Right down to the treetops.  Low as you can.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Fun today.  Like old times.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Danny, what the hell are you trying to do out there?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: What do you mean?  I'm just doing what we've always done.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: No.  You're trying to beat me.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: We've always tried to beat each other.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Bullshit.  We've played with each other, pushed each other.  This is different. Like you want to prove that you're better than me.  Who's that for -- Evelyn?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Maybe just trying to measure up.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: What's between you and her is between you and her.  But here's what's between you and me.  Everybody has a hero, Danny. And you're mine.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: When we were growing up, I had everything.  You had nothing.  You climbed out of a hole I couldn't even see the bottom of.  I think maybe when I went off to England, I was trying to measure up to you.  Measuring up's over.  Let's just look out for each other.  Okay?

Speaker: roosevelt's voice
Dialogue: Good evening, America...

Speaker: roosevelt's voice
Dialogue: I'm told that 80% of American families are listening to these fireside chats of ours, and I'm happy we can come together, as one great American family.  I'd like each of you within the sound of my voice to find a map...

Speaker: roosevelt's voice
Dialogue: Look at the Pacific Ocean.  It covers half the surface of the earth.  And look at the great Atlantic.  The oceans both divide and connect us to our enemies, and either they will come to us, or we will go to them...

Speaker: red
Dialogue: N-naval station?  What's g-going on?

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Wish I knew, Red.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: Want to see where they're going?

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: I guess that settles it.  Somewhere in the Pacific.

Speaker: red
Dialogue: With a s-short r-runway.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: You have rooms at the Biltmore.  I suggest a nice meal and a good night's sleep.  We leave tomorrow.

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: San Francisco, here we are!

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: I don't reckon we can get hogbrains and grits, but I hear a man can eat good in this town.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: I'm gonna turn in.  I hate being on the water.  I think this is the last sleep I'll get for awhile.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: McCawley.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Have fun.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: What?...

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: They were bringing back a ship full of wounded and needed extra nurses along.  I wrote Colonel Doolittle, and told him I needed to see you before you go.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: It must of been a convincing letter.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: It was.  I couldn't have you go away, wherever it is...to war...without knowing something.  You think I made a choice, of Danny over you.  I didn't.  I didn't have a choice.  I'm pregnant.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Does Danny know?

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: I wasn't sure, until the day you turned up alive.  I never had a chance to tell him.  Now I can't have him thinking about this when he needs to be thinking about his mission, and how to come back from it.

Speaker: evelyn
Dialogue: I want you thinking about that too.  Just come back.  Rafe, I see it in your face.  You're thinking you don't have anything to live for.  Don't you dare think that way. I'll never write a letter, or look at a sunset, without thinking of you.  I'll love you my whole life.  And I want you to live.

Speaker: ship's intercom
Dialogue: Army pilots to the briefing room.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I can now tell you that the target of this mission is Tokyo.

Speaker: red
Dialogue: And where's the secret base, Sir?  The one we t-takeoff from.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: The navy will get us to within 400 miles of the Japanese coast.  We'll launch off the carriers from there.

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: Sir, has this ever been done, launching an army bomber off a navy carrier?

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: No.  Any other questions?

Speaker: red
Dialogue: C-Colonel, we been p-practicing takeoff's, but I ain't sure we can land on these carriers d-decks.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: We won't have the fuel to get back to the carriers; they'll turn and run back to Hawaii the minute we're airborne.

Speaker: red
Dialogue: Then wh-where do we land?

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: I have a phrase I want you all to memorize:  "Lushu hoo megwa fugi."  It means "I am an American."  In Chinese.

Speaker: red
Dialogue: A-a-asshole!... Maybe it's l-longer going this way.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: It's shorter than our practice runway.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: They'll turn the ship into the wind before we launch.  That'll help.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: We'll be loaded with 2,000 pounds of bombs and 1,500 pounds of fuel.  I got another Chinese phrase for Doolittle. "Mug wump rickshaw mushu pork."  It means "Who the fuck thought up this shit?"

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: He was a navy man.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Maybe we'll be lucky with the weather.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: Since we'll be on our own once we're in the air, I thought I had a good idea letting each crew select it's own target.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: Now we have fifteen requests for the Emperor's Palace...and one for Tokyo baseball stadium.

Speaker: red
Dialogue: I d-don't think Japs ought'a be allowed to p-play baseball.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: I'd like to bomb their Emperor too.  But I think that'd just piss 'em off.  The idea here, Gentlemen, is not revenge. We're here to prove to them that they're neither invincible nor superior.  So let's try this again.  Military targets only.

Speaker: red
Dialogue: Colonel, to f-fight you need strategy. To have strategy, ya gotta practice.  And to practice it, ya gotta play --

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: No baseball diamonds, Red.

Speaker: red
Dialogue: Y-Yes Sir.

Speaker: admiral
Dialogue: The Enterprise will ride shotgun when we launch the bombers.  They wanted our carriers at Pearl, and now we've come to them.  If the Japanese get us, they'll be having dinner in San Francisco next month.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: It's not getting any longer.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Longer?  It's getting shorter.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: We'll take off late this afternoon.  I'll hit Tokyo at dusk, and drop incendiary bombs.  You'll come after me at night, guided by the fires.  Then it's on to China, where you'll arrive at dawn, guided to their airfields by the homing beacons the Chinese are going to switch on for us.  That's if everything is perfect -- like every other military mission I've ever been involved with.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: Listen you guys.  I'm the first plane -- then McCawley, Walker, the rest of you. I'll have the shortest run.  If I don't make it, you don't go.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Colonel...we're all going.  Whether you make it or not.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Sir, lookouts on the cruisers report patrol boats, ten miles away!

Speaker: halsey
Dialogue: The Japs have set up a picket line! Order the cruisers to open fire!  We've got to sink them before they get a message away.

Speaker: radio operator
Dialogue: They've reported our position!  Tell the Admiral.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: How far are we from Tokyo?

Speaker: admiral
Dialogue: Seven hundred miles.

Speaker: loudspeaker
Dialogue: Army pilots, man your planes!

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: Load in every bit of extra gas you can carry!  And strip everything you don't need out of the planes.  I mean EVERYTHING!

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Broomsticks instead of tail guns.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: We'll get separated over the target, but you and I will rendezvous for the run to China.  I'm on your wing.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: And I'm on yours.  Land of the free.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Home of the Brave.

Speaker: halsey
Dialogue: Of all the other things this mission is doing that have never been done before... I've never sent out planes that I wasn't going to see safely home.  Let's get out of here.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: What's our ETA for Tokyo?

Speaker: navigator
Dialogue: Almost exactly at 12 noon.

Speaker: red
Dialogue: High n-noon.  I k-kinda like that.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: We got a 25-mile-an-hour head wind.  How we doing with fuel?

Speaker: gunner
Dialogue: How do you think?

Speaker: doolittle's navigator
Dialogue: Time for the others to break off.

Speaker: supervisor
Dialogue: From the sea?... That couldn't be right, it must be part of the air raid practice this morning.

Speaker: coma
Dialogue: Listen to this -- it's Tokyo Rose.

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: We'll give that bitch something to announce.

Speaker: japanese mother
Dialogue: Yes!  So beautiful!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Open bomb bay doors.

Speaker: gunner
Dialogue: Bomb bay doors open, sir.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: It's all yours.

Speaker: emperor's attendant
Dialogue: Surely just a drill, Divine One.

Speaker: navigator
Dialogue: Last bomb away.

Speaker: gunner
Dialogue: We got Zeros!  And they're pissed off!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Can you get 'em off us?

Speaker: red
Dialogue: Whatta ya want me to do, sweep 'em!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Danny, get the hell out of here!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Danny, run for the clouds!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: We burned a lot of fuel back there. Flash them and ask about their supply.

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: "How's your fuel?"

Speaker: general marshall
Dialogue: We have bombed Tokyo, Mr. President. Radio Tokyo interrupted it's own broadcast to make the announcement.

Speaker: roosevelt
Dialogue: Have the planes made it to China?

Speaker: general marshall
Dialogue: There've been some complications, Sir. The Chinese didn't receive our request for homing beacons until is was too late to get them set.  And the planes had to take off so early they may lack fuel to make the mainland anyway.

Speaker: roosevelt
Dialogue: So those brave men are flying blind and running out of fuel.

Speaker: general marshall
Dialogue: The Chinese are sending out search parties to try to find the crews before the Jap patrols do, if any of the planes make it.

Speaker: roosevelt
Dialogue: God help them.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: We'll fly till we run out of fuel, then bail out.

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: Chute!

Speaker: doolittle
Dialogue: Nobody else is gonna make it either.  If I live through this, they're gonna put me in Leavenworth Prison.

Speaker: coma
Dialogue: We're running out of fuel.  And I can't find the beacon.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: I don't know if we're over sea or land. Drop flares and try to spot something.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Flash Rafe.  We're gonna bail.

Speaker: red
Dialogue: They've gotta jump.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Not unless we know he's over land!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: You are not bailing out into water!

Speaker: rafe's navigator
Dialogue: Coastline below!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: We've got coast!  Signal him to climb and jump.

Speaker: red
Dialogue: They don't have fuel to make altitude. He's gonna set it down in the water.

Speaker: red
Dialogue: Y-O-U... G-O.  You go on.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: N-O!  We stay together!  I'll go in first.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Hang on tight!  I'll put her in the smooth water and we'll swim in!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: It won't open til the plane fills!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Danny!  DANNY!

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: I've made better landings.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: You hang on, Danny!  You hang on!  You're gonna make it!

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Danny...

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: I can't make it.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Yes you can.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Take care of Evelyn.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: I will.  And your baby.  You're gonna be a father.

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: No.  You are.

Speaker: rafe
Dialogue: Danny... Land of the free... Land of the free...

Speaker: voice over
Dialogue: The Doolittle Raid was the pivotal moment of America's war with Japan.  Before it, America knew nothing but defeat; after it, nothing but victory.  One crew of Doolittle's raiders made it to Vladivostok, Russia, where they were interred for much of the war.  Thirteen planes crash landed in China, where the Chinese people helped the Americans escape, and had their villages destroyed and citizens executed by the Japanese forces of occupation.  Two crews were captured by the Japanese and three fliers were executed without trial, called "war criminals" by the Japanese.  Jimmy Doolittle was promoted to General, and given the medal of honor.
